<div class=WordSection1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span lang=EN-US>Tutorial:
Create a Simple Test</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This tutorial will help you create a simple
test on Concerto, like this:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span lang=EN-US>Login to Concerto</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>It is best to use Google Chrome to run the
Concerto administration panel. </span><span lang=EN-US>Please ensure that you
have Concerto v3.0, the latest version. </span>Go to <b>concerto_installation_path/admin</b>
and login using your credentials. If you haven't installed Concerto on your
server, you can use our demo installation. Email&nbsp;<a
href="mailto:mk583@cam.ac.uk">Michal Kosinski</a>&nbsp;to get demo account.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Demo installation:&nbsp;<a
href="http://dev.myiqtest.org/concerto/admin/">http://dev.myiqtest.org/concerto/admin/</a></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Concept</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>The test you create will be composed of three HTML
Templates:</p>

<ul style='margin-top:0cm' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal><b>Introduction</b>&nbsp;where the user can enter his/her
     name that will be used later in other HTML templates.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal><b>Test questions</b>&nbsp;- with dichotomous (yes/no)
     response options for simplicity at this stage.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal><b>Feedback</b>&nbsp;containing the user's score.</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal>This tutorial is based on a very simple item bank declared
directly in the R script. However, in a proper test it is advisable to use
MySQL to store item banks, user databases, and results. Also, <i>adaptivity</i>
is not used in this tutorial, but you will see how and where a bit of adaptive
code can be added.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Preliminary Step: Creating a test</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Click the ‘tests’ tab on the upper left side of the page.
Click ‘+’ towards the bottom of the list, on the left side of the page, to create
a new test. Assign a relevant name for the test and click ‘OK’. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal>To edit a test (or html template) at any time, click on the
pencil symbol towards the right end of the specific test you want to edit. Be
careful not the click the last symbol on the right (bin) unless you wish to
delete your test!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='background:yellow'>Insert screenshot 1</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Step 1: Create HTML templates</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><i>Introduction Template</i></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0cm' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Click the “HTML templates” tab on the upper left side of
     the page. Click the ‘+’ towards the end of the list of templates. Enter a
     name for the template (e.g. introduction) and click ‘save’ at the bottom
     of the page. </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>User name: Click ‘Text Field’ and enter a name (E.g.
     user_name). Click ‘OK’.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Start: Click ‘Button’ and enter a name (e.g. btn_start),
     text (e.g. Start) and click ‘OK’.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Type in a welcome message and instructions near the
     dialogue box, for users to fill in their name, and start button, for users
     to proceed. </li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal>Don’t forget to save the template!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='background:yellow'>Insert screenshot 2</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><i>Items Template</i></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0cm' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Click the “HTML templates” tab on the upper left side of
     the page. Click the ‘+’ towards the end of the list of templates. Enter a
     name for the template (e.g. items) and click ‘save’ at the bottom of the
     page. </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Response options: Click ‘Radio Button’ and assign a name
     (radio1) and value (0); click ‘OK’. Type <i>No</i> next to it. Similarly,
     create another radio button with the same name but value = 1. Type <i>Yes</i>
     next to it.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Submit: Click ‘Button’ and assign a name (btn_submit) and
     text value (Submit). Click ‘OK’.</li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Edit the template and add suitable text above the radio
     buttons.</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt'>{{user_name}}, please answer the
following question:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt'>{{question}}</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Don’t forget to save the template!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='background:yellow'>Insert screenshot 3</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><i>Feedback Template</i></p>

<ul style='margin-top:0cm' type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Click the “HTML templates” tab on the upper left side of
     the page. Click the ‘+’ towards the end of the list of templates. Enter a
     name for the template (e.g. feedback) and click ‘save’ at the bottom of
     the page. </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal>Edit template and add text suitable for the feedback page,
     including:</li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt'>{{user_name}}, your total score
is {{total_score}}.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Don’t forget to save the template!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='background:yellow'>Insert screenshot 4</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Step 2: Creating an item bank</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Click the ‘tables’ tab on the upper right side of the page
and click ‘+’ at the bottom of the list of available objects to create a new
table. Assign a name and save it.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>To add columns, click ‘+’ just below <i>table structure and
data.</i> Assign a column name (e.g. question) and the type of data it will
contain (i.e. string). Click ‘ok’. Similarly click the ‘+’ on the right side of
the column names to add a second column for answers, consisting of numeric type
data. Your item bank is nearly done.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Now you need to fill the table with the items in your test. To
add rows, click the ‘+’ below the column names. Now, you can directly type in
your items and corresponding answers. For example, see below:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='background:yellow'>Insert screenshot 11</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Don’t forget to save your table!</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b>Step 3: Adding sections to your test</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>This step involves editing your test overall. Click the
‘tests’ tab on the upper left side of the page and click the <i>pencil symbol </i>on
your specific test to edit it. To add a new section, click the ‘+’ at the
bottom of the last section. At this point, the last section is ‘1. start’.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Follow the table below to add new sections, using the
editor. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>
